inference: Hot-water line leak identification
Description: When flow anomaly alerts coincide with sustained temperatures significantly above the cold-water baseline, it indicates that the anomaly is affecting the hot-water side of the system rather than a cold or mixed line, helping localize leaks to hot-water circuits.
short rationale: Localizes leaks but limited behavioral exposure.

inference: Cold-water or mixed-line anomaly identification
Description: Flow anomaly alerts that occur while measured temperatures remain close to ambient or cold baseline suggest that the anomaly is in cold or mixed lines, distinguishing these from hot-only problems and guiding targeted inspection.
short rationale: Line localization with minimal personal insight.

inference: Scalding-risk anomaly detection
Description: Anomalies where temperature trends show rapid spikes to unsafe levels at the same time an alert is raised indicate scalding-risk events, prioritizing those anomalies for urgent intervention compared to anomalies at safe temperatures.
short rationale: Reveals unsafe temperature events during potential use windows.

inference: Heater capacity limit detection during anomalies
Description: When flow anomaly alerts coincide with a noticeable drop in outlet temperature relative to normal operation, it suggests the system is drawing more hot water than the heater can sustain, revealing capacity limits under extreme demand.
short rationale: Shows peak-demand periods with moderate occupancy signal.

inference: Distinguishing leaks from high-demand hot-water usage
Description: If an anomaly corresponds to a long period of moderate flow but temperature stays relatively stable at hot setpoint, it is more consistent with a continuous leak; anomalies where temperature fluctuates as users adjust settings are more likely heavy legitimate use.
short rationale: Differentiates leaks vs user adjustments, linking to usage patterns.

inference: Thermostatic mixing valve malfunction identification
Description: Flow anomaly alerts accompanied by large oscillations in measured temperature, despite steady or slightly elevated flow, suggest a malfunctioning thermostatic mixing valve causing unstable hot–cold mixing during abnormal flow conditions.
short rationale: Equipment fault detection with minimal personal data.

inference: Boiler or heater short-cycling detection
Description: Anomalies marked by frequent, repeated alerts over a short period while temperature trends show cyclical heating and cooling indicate that the boiler or heater is short-cycling under abnormal flow demands.
short rationale: System behavior insight, not user-specific.

inference: Thermal stress hotspot detection in plumbing
Description: Repeated anomaly alerts at very high temperatures over time indicate sections of the system that experience frequent thermal stress, increasing the risk of scale buildup, material fatigue, or joint failure in those zones.
short rationale: Infrastructure stress info with little behavioral exposure.

inference: Seasonal impact on anomaly temperature characteristics
Description: By comparing temperature profiles of anomaly events across seasons, the system can reveal whether anomalies in winter tend to push heaters to maximum temperature, while summer anomalies may be more associated with mixed or cold flows.
short rationale: Seasonal trend, low identifiability.

inference: Detection of overheating during low-flow anomalies
Description: Flow anomaly alerts with relatively low flow but unusually high temperatures suggest inefficiencies where water is being overheated during minor abnormal usages, potentially due to miscalibrated setpoints or faulty thermostats.
short rationale: Shows overheating during small events, modest behavior link.

inference: Pipe freeze-risk anomaly identification
Description: Anomalies where temperatures remain near freezing or abnormally low during flow alerts, especially in cold seasons, indicate conditions where pipes may be exposed to freezing risk despite water movement.
short rationale: Safety risk identification with minimal personal detail.

inference: Temperature-based anomaly prioritization
Description: Linking anomaly alerts with their corresponding temperature profiles allows the system to assign higher priority to anomalies with extreme temperatures (very hot or very cold) and lower priority to those occurring at moderate, non-critical temperatures.
short rationale: Prioritization logic; little behavioral exposure.

inference: Energy waste estimation for hot-side anomalies
Description: For anomalies where temperature is elevated relative to cold baseline, estimate excess thermal energy wasted during the alert window, helping quantify the energy impact of hot-water leaks or overheating issues.
short rationale: Energy cost estimate with minor behavioral signal.

inference: Verification of anomaly cause type via temperature signature
Description: Compare the temperature patterns during anomaly alerts with known signatures—for example, constant high temperature for leaks versus fluctuating temperatures for user-driven events—to refine classification of each anomaly’s root cause.
short rationale: Root cause inference; limited personal data.

inference: Thermal shock anomaly detection in showers
Description: Anomalies overlapping with shower usage windows that show fast swings in temperature (hot–cold or cold–hot) during alerts indicate thermal shock events likely to be perceived as sudden unpleasant changes by users.
short rationale: Exposes in-shower discomfort aligned to routine times.

inference: Failure of temperature-limiting safety mechanisms
Description: When anomalies occur with measured temperatures exceeding configured maximum limits, it indicates a failure or misconfiguration of safety mechanisms that are supposed to cap the temperature even during abnormal flow conditions.
short rationale: Shows extreme temps, slight timing link to usage.

inference: Sensor miscalibration detection using anomaly windows
Description: If flow anomaly alerts occur but the recorded temperature remains perfectly flat or shows unrealistic dynamics, the anomaly–temperature mismatch flags possible miscalibration or placement errors in temperature sensors.
short rationale: Sensor quality check with negligible behavioral info.

inference: Temporal clustering of high-temperature anomalies
Description: Analyze when anomaly alerts occur alongside very high temperatures; clusters in time (e.g., early morning when many showers run) reveal periods where the hot-water system is most stressed and prone to unsafe or unstable behavior.
short rationale: Identifies time windows of heavy hot-water use.

inference: Identification of lukewarm anomaly patterns indicating mixing issues
Description: Anomalies that consistently occur with lukewarm temperatures (mid-range, not hot or cold) suggest unintended mixing or blending caused by faulty valves or cross-connection issues in the plumbing system.
short rationale: Mixing issue flag, minimal personal exposure.

inference: Cooldown behavior after hot-water anomalies
Description: Examine how quickly temperature drops back to normal after hot-side anomaly alerts; slow cooldown indicates high thermal inertia or insulated lines, while fast drops may suggest exposed or poorly insulated pipes.
short rationale: Cooldown characteristic with little behavioral detail.

inference: Recirculation system malfunction detection
Description: Anomalies occurring when temperature remains high even without expected user demand indicate a recirculation system that keeps water hot and moving unnecessarily, causing energy-wasting anomaly alerts.
short rationale: Shows hot circulation during low demand, modest occupancy signal.

inference: Localized overheating vs system-wide temperature rise
Description: By comparing the temperature profile of anomaly events with baseline trends, the system can infer whether anomalies represent local overheating near one fixture or a broader system-wide temperature increase affecting multiple fixtures.
short rationale: Can hint at specific locations but low personal detail.

inference: Scalding near end-of-line fixtures under anomaly conditions
Description: If anomaly alerts coincide with high temperatures specifically at far-end fixtures, it suggests that those fixtures are more vulnerable to scalding during abnormal flow conditions, guiding targeted safety retrofits.
short rationale: Links high temp risk to specific fixtures and times.

inference: Threshold tuning for anomaly detection using temperature context
Description: Cross-analyze the distribution of temperatures during past anomaly alerts; if many alerts occur at safe, moderate temperatures, thresholds may be too sensitive, whereas anomalies consistently associated with extreme temperatures indicate good threshold alignment.
short rationale: Tuning exercise; minimal behavioral exposure.

inference: Self-healing or natural recovery characterization
Description: For anomalies that are not manually intervened, track temperature evolution to see whether the system naturally returns to stable temperature ranges; successful self-recovery suggests flexible thermal resilience, while persistent extremes signal unresolved issues.
short rationale: Recovery pattern; little personal data.

inference: Detection of mixed hot–cold supply interactions during anomalies
Description: Anomaly events where temperature oscillates between near-cold and near-hot values indicate interaction between hot and cold supply lines, possibly due to pressure fluctuations or faulty anti-scald devices.
short rationale: Technical mixing issue with low behavioral impact.

inference: Predictive maintenance indicator from rising hot-anomaly frequency
Description: A rising frequency of anomaly alerts associated with elevated temperatures over weeks or months suggests progressive decline in heater or valve performance, calling for preemptive maintenance before catastrophic failure.
short rationale: Maintenance signal; no user identity.

inference: Validation of post-maintenance improvements
Description: After maintenance or retuning, compare the temperature signatures of new anomaly alerts with historical ones; reduced extreme temperatures during anomalies or fewer hot-temperature alerts indicate successful mitigation of prior issues.
short rationale: Post-maintenance check; negligible behavioral info.

inference: User comfort impact estimation during hot anomalies
Description: When anomalies coincide with typical user usage periods and temperature trends show deviations from usual comfort ranges, the system can estimate how many user sessions were likely affected by discomfort due to thermal anomalies.
short rationale: Connects anomalies to user session timing and comfort.
